Comment: Couple of things, Starlink isn't the only option for satellite internet, it's just the biggest.  Eutelsat for example is also a significant constellation.  Also there are multiple alternatives to GPS, such as GLONASS, Galileo, BeiDou, IRNSS & QZSS.  US control of GPS doesn't stop anything anymore.  The challenge that any competitor has to Starlink though is SpaceX's lift capability.  They are just SO much cheaper than any other lift provider.    But thats the thing, Starlink is only a tiny sliver of SpaceX's potential.  Falcon 9 costs about $2700 to put a kilo into orbit, Ariane 5 is about $9500 per kilo.  Space Shuttle was north of $50k per kilo.  If starship is successful you're looking at \~$200 per kilo to orbit, and you're now in the price range of DHL international shipment.  To put that into perspective, the hubble is roughly 10,000kg.   Sending that up on an Ariane 5 is $95 million, $27 million on a Falcon 9, and \~$2 million on a Starship.  All of a sudden lobbing large payloads to orbit becomes absolutely worthwhile.  Things like ZBLAN optic fiber, which is optic fiber made in zero G are incredibly better than optic fiber made on the ground, become absolutely viable if you can send up the material at 200 per kilo.  Starlink is amazing, but it's a tiny fraction of SpaceX and no way in hell will starlink drag SpaceX into an internet standards body or anything like that.
